abstract.text: An interactive, customizable map view with an interface similar to the one
provided by Apple’s MapKit.

inlineContent.text: Using
, you can embed the map inside a view, allow users to
manipulate it with standard gestures, animate the map between different
viewpoints, and present information in the form of annotations and overlays.
The map view loads scalable vector tiles that conform to the
Mapbox Vector Tile Specification
It styles them with a style that conforms to the
MapLibre Style Spec
Such styles can be designed with
Maputnik
Because
loads asynchronously, several delegate methods are available
for receiving map-related updates. These methods can be used to ensure that certain operations
have completed before taking any additional actions. Information on these methods is located
in the
protocol documentation.
Adding your own gesture recognizer to
will block the corresponding
gesture recognizer built into
. To avoid conflicts, define which
gesture takes precedence. For example, you can create your own
that will be invoked only if the default
tap gesture fails:

code: #selector(myCustomFunction)) for recognizer in mapView.gestureRecognizers! where recognizer is

inlineContent.text: You are responsible for getting permission to use the map data and for
ensuring that your use adheres to the relevant terms of use.

The
class is responsible for marking a point annotation
with a view. Annotation views represent an annotation object, which is an
object that corresponds to the
protocol. When an annotation’s
geographic coordinate is visible in the map view, the map view asks its
delegate to a corresponding annotation view. If an annotation view is created
with a reuse identifier, the map view may recycle the view when it goes
offscreen.
A boolean value indicating whether camera animation duration is set based
on the time difference between the last location update and the current one
or the default animation duration of 1 second.
Place the ornament in the bottom left of the map view.
Triggers a repaint of the map.
A logo, the MapLibre logo by default, positioned in the lower-left corner.
You are not required to display this, but some vector-sources may require attribution.

Adds a single overlay object to the map.
The
protocol defines a set of optional methods that you
can use to receive map-related update messages. Because many map operations
require the
class to load data asynchronously, the map view calls
these methods to notify your application when specific operations complete. The
map view also uses these methods to request information about annotations
displayed on the map, such as the styles and interaction modes to apply to
individual annotations.
Returns the camera that best fits the given shape with some additional padding
on each side while looking in the specified direction.

indicating the position offset of the logo.

handler. This method should be considered “alpha” and as such is subject to
change.
Moves the viewpoint to a different location with respect to the map with an
